- Ahmed, thank you for
joining us on the show today. - Thank you. Thank you for having me. - So before we get started,
what's the story with the cowboy hat? - I went to AWS re:invent last year, which was a few months ago.
I passed a boot barn and I thought, I'm gonna buy myself a cowboy hat. - Okay. What did you do with the hat?

- Oh, you know, I wore
the hat the entire time. It was really good for people
who wanted to get in touch

to find me, because, you know, you'd be in these large exhibition halls, very busy corridors, tens
of thousands of people,

but I was the only one
wearing a cowboy hat. - Okay.
- So I simply say to them, look for the fellow in a cowboy hat,

and they'd come and find me. - So it was basically a
way for people to find you, kind of like finding a
needle in a haystack, right?

- Absolutely. Yeah. - You know, I think that's an apt analogy because a lot of organizations
feel like finding
the right data at the right place at the right time for the right person is like finding a needle in a haystack.

And I think you guys at Firemind know how to do that really well, right? Can you tell us a bit more
about what you guys do?

- Absolutely. Yeah. So, we talk about this
concept called a data story. And what we do with a lot of
our customers is we explain,
okay, data is fine, but so what? If you want to try and find that data,
someone has to think about that data and do something about it. So actually let's think about
why we're trying to find that data, where that data may be, what the frequency could be.

And one of the key issues, again, that we say to a lot of
our customers is then, what do you want to do with that data?

Is it an overload? Are you
showing too many things? Why should that person
care about that data

that's helping them maybe
do their job better? - Okay, so, I mean, I
can imagine a scenario

which I've seen also in many situations where they don't really
know what they're gonna do with their data initially,

especially if they have
so much data coming from different data sources. So is there like a, let's say,
a independent of the use case way to build up a mature data practice?

- Absolutely. We generally ask four questions when we're talking about a
data practice or a strategy

or whatever you kind of
want to call it, right? The first thing we say is, actually,

give us a number for which
having access to the data, or your organization, or whoever,

having access to data
will move that number and promote that number
in a positive direction.

Whether it's up, whether it's down, whether it's the same,
for example, you know, give us a number. It can't be revenue.

But it could be something
that affects revenue. So productivity for example,
is a great one to look at. Full-time employee hours.

We then ask them, explain
why that number is important? Of course, every company wants
to be more productive, right?

If your staff are more productive, they get an hour back every week, you think of that across a
large enterprise organization,
huge productivity increase. We then start looking where that data is, is it readily accessible?

Are there controls
around it? Is there PII? Do we have to think about
anything around compliance?
And also, wrangling the data. You know, there's great tools on the cloud to help us wrangle that data

and make it available when
it needs to be available to the person. And then the fourth one is,
actually, who is that person?

What is their role that
will consume that data, where that data is, that will
positively affect that number?

Because it's always down to
someone within this process and we try to help them understand, okay,

what are they going to do with that data? How can they action that
data rather than having to think about doing something with it?

- Right. Right. So it all has to be anchored to some kind of business value
at the end of the day, right? - Absolutely correct. Yeah, yeah.

We have to show that we
are moving the boat faster. - So, you know, a lot of organizations

want to implement AI and
machine learning now, and sometimes it feels like maybe
people are saying we wanna implement it for the sake of implementing it. Is there any inherent value in it,

or do those projects also have
to be tied to business value? - We try to tie everything
to business values.

What we tend to do is we
will work with the customer and we will draw a quadrant of, you know,
deliverability and business impact. Obviously we want stuff that is highest

in terms of deliverability, so it's easy to deliver
and highest business value. And we'll work with the business
and help them understand

that, actually, implementing
a data strategy, implementing AI/ML is
incredibly beneficial.

And you can start small. So even if you just
want to implement AI/ML for the sake of AI/ML, actually,

it's very easy to find use
cases within your organization for which we can hone in that
use case, find that number,

and then draw value as
well as doing something because you want to do it. - Okay, so your decision criteria

for helping an organization
to make the right decision about how to implement AI/ML

is not just a function
of the business value, it's also a function of the practicality or feasibility of delivering it, right?

- Correct. Absolutely correct. Whatever we talk about, we have to say that
we're building everything

to the standards that they require and to the standards that
the industry requires as well that we would see amongst ourselves.

So we would always talk about, you know, the Well-Architected Framework on AWS, ensuring everything is resilient,
scalable, cost effective,

and secure, of course. So, you could deliver ultimately
anything on the cloud,

right, you could probably do anything. But actually some things are
technically easier to deliver

and will drive higher business value than things that will be
inherently hard to deliver and may have lower business value.

- Right, right, and finding
that magic quadrant, as they say sometimes, is the
key really to make it work.

- Absolutely correct. And it's all about
engaging with the customer, running workshops with them. I'm a huge believer of
going to the coalface,

finding those people
that are doing, you know, high effort, low value work.

And saying to them,
it's fine, that's okay, but if I can save you an hour
within your organization,
you know, every day, for example, by helping automate this process as part of a greater strategy,

that's a massive productivity increase. - I like what you said
about finding people that are doing high effort,
but low value or low output.
Bit of a philosophical question, what is actually the value of AI/ML? Is it saving effort?
Is it making more revenue? Is it improving customer experience? Why even start to try and implement AI/ML?
- So I use a great analogy. If you're old enough like me, you may remember the A-Z books.

How often do you use an A-Z
book to get around London? You don't.
- Never, yeah. - You use Citymapper, right?
Or Google Maps or Apple Maps or whatever. So AI/ML is around us everywhere,

looking at traffic in real time, looking at data in real time, looking at routes in real time. So we are already as
humans using technology
to help us be more productive. So the discussion we have with customers whom are doing high effort,
low value work is actually, you can use AI/ML to free you from this,

I guess, approach
whereby you are accepting a business-as-usual status quo

that I have to follow this process. Well actually machine
learning is about probability.

Us humans are about probability. We can have a machine do that process because you as an expert
in that subject matter

at the coalface able to understand what's happening within the business, it's more important for
you to then apply yourself

and do creative work
that is of higher value than it is to simply
do the high effort work
just because you can. - Yeah. Yeah. So it's kind of like we're offloading these very procedural things that we do
that maybe a machine could do better to free up time for us humans,

basically to produce
things that are creative, things that require ambiguity,

things where the process is unknown, things where uniquely
humans can add value. - Absolutely. Correct.

And this is what's really magical because then you understand just how much data there
is within organizations

and actually just how much external data organizations may reference. So one thing that's very
interesting that we see

with a lot of organizations
is they'll say to us, well, here's our data lake, here's, you know, our data
warehouse, lake house,

whatever you want to call it. But actually we'll find
maybe 60 to 75% of the time,

they're actually using external data for which they don't reference because it's not within
their internal systems.

And that external data
could look at things like compliance, regulatory information, it could be competitor
information, for example,
all of which is very unstructured. And because it's a third party data,
you can't control it. You can't control the frequency. Naturally, it's very easy to go,
I will throw humans at it. You know, I'll throw interns at it. And they'll do X, Y, Z,

and then you end up having
PowerPoints and dashboards and all these things and
you just end up having all this noise without
actually saying, well,

if I apply machine learning to the thought process
of inferring that data,

and I bring that into
a correct data strategy that includes our internal data, then actually, you have a
large amount of possibilities,

including scenario planning, including modeling and forecasting by going back in time and
asking what if, you know,

with kind of the horizon scanning and the view of the world that
machine learning gives us.

- So, there is a gap that I'm seeing. I think the value that you're
communicating is clear.

I think a lot of people
know it intuitively. But still, and according to Gartner, 85% of AI/ML projects fail
to produce a return for a business. Why do you think that is? Why do so many projects fail to deliver?

- I think because they're
probably not scoped correctly. I think because they
haven't really sat down and thought to themselves,

is this actually going to move the boat? I did the conference
for AWS back in October

for business transformation, and on stage I asked, so what? So what you did an AI/ML
project, what's the point?

What does business as usual look like? The whole point of
trying to implement that is so that it goes into business as usual

and that business as usual
helps move the boat faster. So, I'm not surprised by that because I think, like you said earlier,

a lot of the time people
do them as vanity projects without thinking about the, 'so whats.'
- Okay. Now that brings us into gen AI, right?

Gen AI is getting massive
interest these days, and I know you guys at
Firemind are working on a lot of gen AI engagements.
So, what are the steps do you think an organization needs to take

to make it successful
to avoid that 85% trap of even classical machine
learning projects?

- I think the biggest thing
organizations need to understand when it comes to anything
about machine learning,
especially gen AI, is that they have to shift their mindset to a probabilistic mindset.

So, I get in front of
customers and I say to them, we are used to computers
being zero and one.

As we're recording this video, I t's writing zeros and ones
to something, somewhere.

And that's what people will watch. But that's not what machine learning is. Machine learning, like us as
humans, is about probability.

Of course, there are deterministic
machine learning models, but for the sake of
purpose of generative AI, it's about probability.

We say to a lot of our customers, you have to embrace the
concept that it could be wrong

and you have to work out
your acceptable precision because if you are saying

that you always need a
hundred percent accuracy, we then have to think about
what that really looks like

in terms of machine
learning and data as well. But if you are willing to
that actually, as a human,

as part of a process you
already have implemented, they're right 80 to 90% of the time.

Well, so are machine learning models. And once customers shift
their mindset to, actually,

we as humans and everything
around us is about probability, they can understand really
how machine learning

and generative AI can add
value to their business. - Can you give an example of that? Like, maybe a use case or
an engagement you've seen

where that shift needed to
happen, and when it happened, it started to make things successful? - Absolutely, so one of the
most fundamental applications
of generative AI that we use is helping our FSI insurance customers

understand what's happening
in their call center. So we will take call center information, we will use transcribe,

and then we will run a
number of generative AI and ML task against that information. Because here in the
UK, FCA guidance states

that an insurance company, for example, must adhere to a certain number
of principles and guidance

when it comes to vulnerable customers. So, one key thing a lot of
our FSI insurance customers are asking us is,

how do I know if this
customer is vulnerable without someone calling up
and saying, I am vulnerable?
No one does that. So how do we use machine learning with generative AI to interpret,

to understand what's being
said within that transaction between the customer and
the call agent to go,

this looks like a vulnerable customer. And then alert to the call agent, okay, this is what you should
do because FCA guidance

says X, Y, Z, you should follow X, Y, Z. The complete hypothesis
there is, actually,

we take all of that data and we say to our insurance customer, your script that you are
running in the call center
is actually a median performing agent, but what does a better, good, the best performing agent look like?

How do you then redo that
training to all your agents, provide them with the best tools possible
to give their customers not only, you know, regulated advice, but also the best advice

to give you a competitive
edge against your customers? And that's a real life example there.

- And in that example, what is the shift from binary to probabilistic
that you're talking about?

Like, what did they need
to change in their mindset to embrace the more probabilistic world

when it comes to machine learning? - Absolutely, so vulnerability is a really, really interesting one. - Because people can be
vulnerable in different ways.

For example, you could have absolutely everything tied down. You could be on top of
absolutely everything

and then there could be bereavement. And that bereavement could
trigger a series of events that, you know, makes your
world crumble basically.
Suddenly, that person is vulnerable having to call up car insurance to cancel

because they're dealing
with a bereavement, right? So, to a call agent,
there is a set script.

They've come in this way,
it's a midterm adjustment, they have to follow this
thing, 50 pound fee.

But actually this person is
dealing with a bereavement. We have empathy as humans, but the script is telling
me I have to apply
a 50 pound cancellation fee. Using generative AI to go, well, actually,

it looks like you're
dealing with a bereavement. And although the script says this, our guidelines and FCA
guidelines and all that,

say actually, you should waive that fee. So, although the script will
be binary, zero and one,
this is what you should follow, using AI to help that agent make a better, customer-focused decision
is truly important. And then truly drives up NPS scores of that insurance company.

- But the CDO of that insurance company needs to take the leap of
faith that, you know what, the gen AI recommendation
may be incorrect.

Maybe the person is
vulnerable or maybe not, and we might overcharge or undercharge in certain situations,

but overall it would be a net positive and we need to be comfortable
with those failure rates.
- You're absolutely correct. You are absolutely correct. Nothing is certain. And this is why, for example,
we talk about the 'so what.' Now that we've deployed this thing, okay, what does business as usual look like?
What do our recall rates look like? Are we 80 to 90%? Do we need to add some fine-tuning?

Do we need to add some
training, for example? Do we need to add some
special logic to this machine to help understand
specifically how the FCA

wants an agent to act, or how the insurance company
wants the agent to act? Or maybe there's a new
type of vulnerability

that we're not aware of. This is exactly the point,
where you're saying, projects fail, because they
get to a point in time,

and go, ah, well, that
machine learning project was only good up till now. And we talk about, well,

what's the next, what's the 'so what?' When does bias, when does
doubt, when does drift occur? And how do we deal with
that with our customers

to make sure they're getting the best out of the
technology that's available? - I think part of it, as well,

is this discomfort with having a machine accountable
for something, right?

If a human makes a mistake, or they have a certain failure rate, we're comfortable with that because we can hold a
certain human accountable.

But if a machine makes a
mistake, what do you do? It's like the trolley problem
with self-driving cars. You know, it's very tragic,
difficult, ethical dilemma.

If you have somebody
vulnerable in front of you, do you swerve out of the way and hit somebody else who's vulnerable?

Or, how do you calculate, let's say, the collateral damage,
for lack of a better term?

This is a big problem. And I think a lot of
people who are in charge who need to make the decision
of implementing gen AI,

or even just regular AI
and machine learning, they're in a position where they need to codify their ethics in a way.
And that's an issue that is ongoing. Have you seen any kind of discomfort

from somebody you've worked with, on something like that?
- Absolutely. Absolutely. And I reference a great AWS term,
think big, start small, scale fast. We're not here to try and bore the ocean.

Let's start small, let's
start somewhere isolated, and let's build and let's learn
and let's scale from there.

The other thing as well
with the trolley problem is I always say, well, why does no one press the break, okay?

Let's apply guardrails, you know? This is the exact discussion
we have with customers. Okay, fine. The machine will be 80% right.

So how do we put in
certainty for that last 20% where we can't be sure the
machine can be correct?

So we put in additional checks, additional guardrails, maybe a human in the loop, for example, to do as much as we can
to get as close to 100%.

And that's the approach we take. Every use case is different. Every CDO, every
organization is different.

But the beautiful thing
about machine learning, and actually the beautiful
thing about generative AI, is that now we can reason
using natural language.

We don't have to have people
that understand data science. Not saying that we shouldn't
be using data scientists,

but it means that we can
put it in front of Bob, who is speaking to
customers every single day,

and try to understand how

- So, how do we make gen AI real? Who actually needs it, and when?

And if they decide, if we
find out that we do need it, how do we make it work on
the ground, pragmatically?
- That's a very good question. The honest answer is that gen AI is part of a suite of tools.
Again, you know, we focus on data, AI, ML. Gen AI is part of our arsenal,

our Swiss army knife,
when we come to customers. It may not be for
everyone, and that's okay.

You don't have to always
have the newest shiny thing. We use generative AI in pretty
much all of our use cases,

because actually what
generative AI allows us to do, like I was saying earlier, is that it allows us
to reason with a model

just using natural language. And this is incredibly powerful because we could have a
pipeline, for example,

whereby we're running through
several pieces of data, but someone then wants to
go, how does that work?

Can you explain that for me? Can I potentially reason with it? Because in my head I
have a chain of thought

how I want to reason with that data, and I'm going to explain that
to you in natural language, and I want you to take that
and then give it to a machine.

Better yet, we give them a
sandbox and say hey, listen, cut us out. Take it for a few weeks.

And actually, you explain to the machine, and you validate with the machine. Your chain of thought
becomes its chain of thought

and you ask it why it

doing is we're empowering. We're empowering people who
have been stuck in a process,

stuck with certain tools that
didn't do everything they did, and their human aspect, had
to deal with that as a buffer,

giving them that ability to kind of define their own process. And that's where generative
AI becomes so powerful here,
because anyone can use it to put down their chain of thought against that data they want to reason against.
